Introduction

This policy provides information and guidance to Registered Nurses, Healthcare Assistants, Allied Health professionals and Medical staff who work within in-patient and out-patient settings, to ensure a consistent and safe approach across the Trust in the assessment, and management of wounds regardless of aetiology, cause or duration.
Purpose
The policy aims to support the delivery of consistent, high quality, individualised wound care by clinical staff for all patients requiring wound related care within the Trust by:
setting out a standardised and holistic approach to wound care, whilst taking into account individuals' preferences and beliefs
setting out expected standards for effective wound management which is delivered by staff with the appropriate knowledge and skills
acknowledging that for some patients symptom control and management is the treatment aim when wound healing is not the primary objective i.e. for palliative patients

providing information and guidance for clinicians in order to support use of clinically effective wound management dressings and ensuring they are utilised appropriately to support optimum wound healing, patient comfort and cost effectiveness
Scope

This policy relates to the care and management that patients should receive if they have either a wound present on admission as an in-patient to the Trust, develop a wound during their in-patient episode of care, or are attending a wound related out- patient appointment.

The policy applies to all clinical staff, both permanently employed, or working as bank or agency employees, who work in clinical areas covering either out-patient departments or in-patient Wards / Units/ Theatres / Post-operative room. This includes but is not limited to medical staff, nurses, Allied Health care professionals and health care assistants.
All clinical staff working within the Trust are expected to adhere to this policy.
This policy is relevant to:
Emergency Care Departments;
Out-patient Departments
In-patient facilities / Units / Wards;
Day Assessment Units
Operating Theatres/ Recovery room
The Policy is relevant for:
Nursing and Health Care Assistants
Theatre staff
Medical staff
Tissue Viability Team
Allied Health Care professional
Aims and Objectives
To support consistent individualised high quality wound management care for all patients being cared for within the Trust by:
Providing a standardised and holistic approach to wound care whilst taking account of an individual's preferences and beliefs
Providing effective wound care delivered by staff who have the appropriate wound management knowledge and skills
Establishing continuity of wound care across the Trust
Promoting cross boundary and multi professional working in the best interests of the patient
Ensuring that a multidisciplinary approach is taken to address all of the needs of the patient where appropriate
Informing clinicians of the best practice in wound care management.
Ensuring a comprehensive wound assessment is undertaken in a timely manner, and appropriate evidence-based treatment plans commenced
Ensuring an equitable and standardised approach to wound management takes place

Ensuring that appropriate wound management dressings, including advanced dressings (e.g. Topical Negative Therapy dressings) are available and utilised as and when required in order to meet the patients' individual needs

Ensuring that those who undertake wound assessment, planning, implementation and evaluation of wound care have had appropriate education and training in wound management prior to undertaking wound care related procedures
Providing symptom control and management when the primary objective is not wound healing i.e. for palliative patients

Ensuring there is a Tissue Viability link nurse for each Ward / department / out- patient department that provides wound care to support the Tissue Viability Team who will lead on wound management within each ward/department.
Definitions

table_items.text: One that has attained complete skin closure without drainage or dressing requirements.

The growth of new blood vessels stimulated by local environmental factors such as low oxygen tension, low pH and high lactate levels. Also, certain mediators act as angiogenic signals for endothelial cells (Enoch 2004)

a structured community of microbes with genetic diversity and variable gene expression that creates behaviours and defences used to produce unique infections (chronic infection). Biofilms are characterised by significant tolerance to antibiotics and biocides while remaining protected from host immunity.

A clear definitive and standardised definition of a cavity wound does not exist. The literature provides different definitions of what constitutes a cavity wound including, amongst these, any wound that extends into the dermis and exposes underlying structures for example tendon, muscle and bone. A cavity can exist in most wound types, and can result from, for example, surgical intervention, and subsequent wound dehiscence, traumatic wounds, chronic wounds such as pressure ulcers, diabetic foot, leg ulcers, or malignant wounds. A cavity wound may present with additional features of undermining, sinus or fistula formation, bridging. Types of cavity wounds are set out in Appendix 1. See Cavity Wound Packing Guidance SOPN054
Epithelialisation Pink to white smooth looking tissue
Cells at the edges of the wound spread over the wound until it is covered. This happens when the granulation tissue is level with the surrounding skin.
A generic term given to liquid produced from chronic or acute wounds once haemostasis is achieved
This describes the new wound matrix which provides the scaffolding for new capillaries to grow into in order to form connective tissue (Enoch 2004).
New tissue formed in the wound is called granulation tissue. It is red to pink in colour.
A wound that has not responded to evidence-based standard of care.

The use of the larvae of the green bottle fly (Lucilia Sericata) which feed on dead tissue, debris and microbes. Larvae work by liquefying devitalised tissue; they do this by producing secretions that break down the dead tissue into semi liquid form which they are able to ingest. They do not feed on living tissue. They also cannot dig, tunnel or burrow into healthy tissue. They have an antibacterial effect by ingesting any bacteria, fungi or viruses that are in the liquefied tissue; this action reduces the bioburden in the wound and can help prevent biofilm forming in the wound. See SOP MSESOP-21012 Safe and effective use of larvae therapy.

A softening of the skin due to prolonged exposure to moisture and proteolytic enzymes, which predisposes skin to breakdown. Macerated skin is usually pale but if inflamed may become red” (Voegeli 2012 cited in Wounds International 2019).
Necrosis or eschar: black / dark grey tissue
Is tough and leathery when dehydrated. Wound eschar is full thickness, dry devitialised tissue due to prolonged local ischaemia. Necrotic tissue acts as a barrier epithelialisation
Undamaged capillaries beneath the wound sprout buds which grow towards the surface and loop over and back to the capillary. The loops form a network within the wound supplying oxygen and nutrients
Usually creamy yellow fibrinous material that can be either dehydrated and firmly adhered to the wound bed or loose and stringy in the presence of increased exudate.

A substance that is used in a cleansing solution to lower the surface or interfacial tension between a liquid and a solid (for example debris or biofilm), and which helps to disperse the solid, which can then be removed more easily with gauze, a cleansing pad or cloth. The surfactant increases the ability of the solution to spread over the wound surface and penetrate wound coatings, lifting bacteria and debris and suspending them in the solution. Such solutions may also help to disrupt and remove bacterial biofilms in the wound (Braun M, McGrath A, Downie F. www.wounds-uk.com/made-easy).

“A break in the epithelial integrity of the skin. However, the disruption can be deeper, extending to the dermis, subcutaneous fat, fascia muscle or even the bone”. This may result from physical, mechanical or thermal damage, or develop as a result of an underlying medical or physiological disorder. For example: Physical damage: pressure ulcers Mechanical damage: abrasions, grazes, lacerations, knife wounds (surgery), bullet wounds or bites. Thermal damage: burns caused by flames, chemicals, radiation, friction or electricity and frostbite. Medical or physiological disorders: arterial or venous

ulcers, autoimmune, endocrine, dermatological or haematological disorders, wounds associated with certain systemic infections, malignant diseases or neuropathy. Wound healing is a collective term for the physiological processes that repair and restore damaged skin tissue. Wounding and healing involve a complex series of molecular, cellular and chemical interactions and processes and involves a whole body response; the individual should be assessed and treated as a whole, not just the visible injury.

Removal of devitalised or infected tissue, fibrin or foreign material from a wound (‘debris). This can be removed by the body through the natural wound healing process. However wound healing can be delayed if there are large amounts of debris within the wound which can also provide an environment for infection.

Inevitable outcome following a chain of dynamic interactions between a host, a potential pathogen, and the surrounding environment. The presence of micro-organisms within a wound can damage tissue, delay healing and potentially cause systemic illness.

Wound Management principles

Clinical effectiveness in wound healing is achieved with a standardised and structured approach to wound care. Practice should be based on current, available evidence. This improves patient outcomes, and ensures a positive patient experience
Effective wound management requires an understanding of the skin and its functions (See Appendix 2), the wound healing process, and appropriate dressing selection and use (Appendix 3).
Types of wounds
Acute Wound: the aetiology occurs suddenly either with or without intention, but that heals in a timely manner. Includes including surgical and traumatic wounds.

Clean surgical wounds will heal by primary intention where the skin edges are brought together using sutures, clips, adhesive strips or glue. Acute wounds proceed through the healing process in a timely manner as they generally have no underlying aetiology to disrupt a normal inflammatory response. Acute wounds that do not heal within four to six weeks or develop complications that delay healing may then be described as chronic.

Chronic Wounds: including pressure ulcers, leg ulcers, fungating lesions, diabetic foot ulcers. They will heal by secondary intention, when skin edges are not brought together as demonstrated in cavity wounds, leg ulcers, sinuses, dehisced surgical wounds. Chronic wounds are generally characterised by the presence of underlying pathology and are generally associated with a persistent state of inflammation which prolongs or interrupts the healing process.

This type of wound has a slow progression through the wound healing phases, or shows delayed, interrupted or stalled healing due to intrinsic or extrinsic factors that impact on the individual and their wound. A chronic, non-healing wound could be suggestive of a biofilm, providing holistic evaluation has excluded or corrected underlying pathologies such as ischaemia.

Chronic wounds start as acute wounds but become stuck in the inflammatory or proliferative stage. They are involved in a circular rather than linear process. This is due to alteration or stalling within the normal cellular and molecular processes. Healing may be impeded by the presence of necrotic tissue or slough.

Non-Healing wounds: For some patients healing is not achievable, for example, with some foot/leg ulcers or malignant fungating wounds. The primary goals of care should be to maximise patient comfort and control symptoms such as exudate, odour and pain. The decision that a wound is ‘non-healing' should be made by the multi-disciplinary team that includes the Tissue Viability Nurse Specialist.
Categories of Tissue loss
Partial thickness: Involves damage/loss of epidermal and dermal layers of skin
Full thickness: Involves damage and loss of epidermal, dermal and subcutaneous layers of skin. Tendon, muscle and bone may be exposed.
Wound assessments should include a description of the type and amount of tissue present for example: epithelialising, granulating, sloughy, necrotic or non-healing
Factors contributing to delayed wound healing
An individual's ability to heal and the time required to heal can vary greatly and are influenced by the following factors which should be taken into consideration during assessment.
General physical and psychological health. Type and level of concurrent illnesses; systemic and local
Levels of bacterial colonisation and local wound or systemic infection
Nutrition: consideration should be made regarding referral to the Dietetics Department for all patients with complex wounds depending on the outcome of the patient's nutritional assessment
Infection: specific reference should be made to the Infection, Prevention and Control Policy where appropriate
Malignant disease
Diabetes – diabetic ulceration should be assessed and managed by the Wound Management Team
Poor blood supply/peripheral vascular disease/cardiovascular disease
Presence of foreign bodies
Excess debris
Anaemia
Rheumatoid Arthritis
History of smoking and/or alcohol consumption
Medications for example steroids, anti-inflammatory, immunosuppressant's, anti-coagulants
Patient concordance to care advice
Environment
The wound healing process
Wounds heal by either:
Primary intention: wound edges of a are brought together and held by sutures, clips, staples. This promotes restoration of anatomic and functional integrity
Secondary intention: wound edges cannot be drawn together because of extensive tissue loss, or large surface areas. Healing occurs through granulation and epithelialisation.
Tertiary intention: where the injury/defect is initially left to heal by secondary intent with an aim to achieve complete closure by primary intent as soon as is possible
Wound healing proceeds through a complex process of four overlapping but well- defined phases:
Haemostasis

If penetrated, the dermis will bleed. The damaged ends of blood vessels constrict to form a clot. This holds the damaged tissues together to form a fibrin mesh. This is the scaffold in which scar tissue will be deposited. The platelets trapped in the clot are essential for haemostasis and for a normal inflammatory response.
Platelets start the healing process by attracting a host of different cells into the wound.
Inflammation
The inflammatory process is often triggered as a result of trauma, surgery or through homeostatic imbalance (Adderley, 2010).
11.3.1 This phase stimulates the proliferation and maturation phases, It involves numerous cells including platelets, neutrophils, lymphocytes, macrophages and epithelial cells.

11.3.2 During this stage inflammatory mediators, such as prostaglandins and histamines, are released from mast cells stimulated by tissue damage and clotting factors. This causes vessels next to the injury to become more permeable and to vasodilate.

11.3.3 The inflammatory stage is the precursor to the next stages of healing. Patients who do not produce an adequate inflammatory response may fail to progress through the other stages of normal wound healing.

11.3.4 In chronic wounds this stage is delayed. Wounds can become stuck due to an alteration or stalling within the normal cellular and molecular processes. They are involved in a circular rather than linear process.
11.3.5 The clinical signs of inflammation are
Redness
Heat
Swelling
Pain
11.3.6 Inflammation prepares the wound bed by:
Ensuring it is free from bacteria and other foreign materials
Creating an optimum environment for epithelial cells to multiply
11.3.7 This stage lasts about 4-5 days and can be divided into early and late inflammation:
Early Inflammatory stage
Neutrophils (white blood cells) are the first inflammatory cells to arrive at the injury site within a few hours of injury. They are responsible for:
Killing bacteria
Breaking down foreign material and devitalised tissue by releasing degrading enzymes
11.4.1  They die off after a few days.
Late Inflammatory stage

After two - three days macrophages replace neutrophils at the wound site. They are present throughout wound healing. They are the most important cells in the late inflammatory stage as a key regulatory cell for repair.
11.5.1 They have a dual role in wound healing:
Ingestion of bacteria, devitalised tissue, depleted neutrophils
Transition from the inflammatory to the proliferative stage of healing

11.5.2 Slough formation is common during the inflammatory stage which occurs as a result of the accumulation of dead cellular debris. It is usually creamy yellow in colour. It may combine with fibrous tissue to cover the wound base which is hard to remove.
Proliferation
11.6.1 This starts at about day three and lasts for about two weeks after injury. During this stage there is a decrease in wound size by a combination of:
granulation
contraction
epithelialisation
11.6.2 The wound is replaced with newly formed granulation tissue. This tissue consists of macrophages, fibroblasts, immature collagen, blood vessels and ground substance (Dealey & Cameron 2008).
11.6.3 Granulation describes the new wound matrix which provides the scaffolding for new capillaries to grow into in order to form connective tissue.
11.6.4 Wound contraction starts on about day five or six post injury. It may be responsible for 40-80% of the closure (Dealey and Cameron 2008).
11.6.5 Epithelialisation occurs when macrophages stimulate the proliferation and migration of epithelial cells which:
Divide and migrate over the surface of granulation tissue until they form a continuous cover
Only move over viable tissue and require a moist wound environment
Are slowed down by necrotic tissue or a scab as they are forced to burrow under them
Are whitish pink in colour and originate from the wound margin or from remnants of hair follicles, sebaceous glands, or sweat glands
Maturation
This begins at about day twenty and can last for years. The wound becomes less vascularised and may only ever regain 80% of its strength.
11.7.1  Scar tissue is avascular, contains no hair, sebaceous glands or sweat glands and is formed as a normal consequence of tissue repair in adults.
Wound Management
T.I.M.E.S framework
This framework enables the clinician to use a structured, logical and systematic approach to wound care, and can guide wound management of all wound types. The elements of the framework are:
Tissue management
Inflammation/infection
Moisture balance
Edges
Surrounding skin
12.1.1 See Appendix 5

12.1.2 The framework enables the clinicians to identify barriers to healing such as necrotic tissue, wound infection, and develop and implement a plan to address these in order to promote wound healing.
12.1.3 The T.I.M.E.S framework should form part of the overall holistic assessment of the patient. The findings can then be used to guide treatment of the patient and their wound.
12.1.4 The plan for managing wounds should involve the patient at all points to aid concordance and include:
Holistic patient assessment including identification of factors that may delay healing
Comprehensive wound assessment and on-going reassessment
Appropriate treatment objectives and regular wound evaluation
Appropriate dressings selection
Appropriate use of antibiotics for wound infection
Documentation of the outcomes and effective care planning / reassessment
Holistic patient assessment
Effective wound management should involve a full patient assessment that is carried out at regular intervals. The assessment should include:
The patient's goals of care / preferences / choice; if the patient is unable to advice, consult with the family or significant others
Past medical / psychosocial history – identifying any factors that may impact on wound healing
Wound history
Risk assessments:
Waterlow and Nutritional risk assessment score
Continence assessment
Manual handling assessment
Fall assessment
Factors such as body size and weight, smoking, concordance to care plans
Pain assessment and ensuring effective pain control is in place and effectiveness is documented, monitored and adjusted accordingly
Medication prescribed (this can impact wound healing)
Allergies (includes to dressings, tapes).
General skin assessment
Pressure relieving equipment provision in line with patient need and circumstances
Level of mobility - if the patient is able to reposition independently or requires assistance to do so and the impact on manual handling
Patient acceptability, including manual handling and transfer
Impact of equipment on patient's independence and if there is an increased falls risk for example with an alternating mattress or cushion)

Vascular assessment in the case of heel pressure ulcers / lower limb ischaemia (e.g. history of claudication, and ankle brachial index or toe pressure). Referral to the Vascular Team may be required to support / direct effective and timely wound management
Laboratory tests and x-rays as required.
12.2.1  Document the outcome of this assessment in the patient record.
Wound Assessment
A comprehensive wound assessment should be undertaken with reference to the T.I.M.E.S framework before the use of a specific wound dressing regime is devised.

12.3.1 The purpose of wound assessment is to record baseline information regarding the patient's wound(s), and to allow the health care practitioner to make clinical judgements and treatment plan decisions based upon this. The assessment also acts as means of identifying and recording changes in the wound.
12.3.2 A specific and comprehensive wound assessment should be undertaken by a doctor, registered nurse or student nurse (only under the supervision of a registered nurse) on:
Initial identification of the wound:
First dressing change following surgery
At each subsequent dressing change
12.3.3 The wound assessment should include the following:
Wound type: (for example pressure ulcer, leg ulcer venous or arterial, surgical wound, diabetic foot ulcer, fungating ulcer, burn or traumatic injury)
Anatomical wound location

Wound size: taken at initial identification and at least weekly (length, depth and width measurements in centimetres using a disposable tape measure. Include areas of undermining / tunnelling; document undermining using the clock face method. Document the position the patient is in when taking measurements to enable consistency of measurement.
Pain assessment and ensuring appropriate level of analgesia is prescribed to cover dressing change
Medical photography
Identification of local barriers to healing such as excess exudate, presence of necrotic tissue, infection
Exudate – type, colour, amount, thickness, smell
Type of tissue present – e.g. granulation, slough, necrosis
Signs of wound infection (See Appendix 5).
Condition of the wound edges
Condition of the surrounding skin
Wound Reassessment
Undertake at each dressing change and at least weekly if the patient remains in hospital to:
Monitor the appropriateness of the current wound care regime
Respond to treatment changes following re-assessment
Adjust the care plan as required
Ensure the patient receives appropriate care based on a holistic assessment
Ensure the wound care plan remains acceptable to the patient and they consent to it
Document findings and any changes to care plan
12.4.1 Observe the patient's wound for developments which may indicate the need to change the treatment e.g. wound improvement or deterioration, more or less exudate, signs of infection.

12.4.2 For some patients it must be acknowledged that the goal is not to achieve complete wound closure. Rather symptom control is the primary aim for example exudate and odour control and effective pain management
Datix Incident reporting
A Datix incident report should be completed if required following wound assessment. Select the appropriate category from the drop down selection.

12.5.1  A safeguarding referral should be made in line with the Safeguarding policy (Adult and Children) if there is a safeguarding concern identified as an outcome of the wound assessment/ holistic assessment.
Documentation
Document the outcome of all wound related assessments and reassessment.

12.6.1 Use the Trust approved wound assessment templates and wound related care plans. Complete these documents on identification of a wound and thereafter in line with instructions on the document (this is usually on identification, on change of wound condition or at least weekly).
12.6.2 Ensure patient consent to wound related care plans / procedures is gained and documented.
12.6.3 Update all documentation in a timely and accurate manner reflecting accurately changes to the wound and care plan.
12.6.4 Ensure wound management care plans are in place and are accurate and appropriate and evaluated at least weekly or on change of condition.
12.6.5 Ensure each of the patient's wounds is documented separately and has a care plan in place. Update on change of wound condition and review at least weekly to ensure it remains appropriate.
Care planning for pressure ulcer prevention and management
Commence a preventative care plan within 6 hours of admission and review /update if a change in patient's medical condition or pressure ulcer status
Commence pressure ulcer care plan and document all care interventions.
Complete wound care template / electronic wound care plan
Review / update at least weekly or on change of wound condition
Using the T.I.M.E.S framework to support wound assessment and reassessment
T = Tissue Type

13.1.1 The type of tissue within the wound plays an important role in wound healing. This will change throughout the healing process with the amount of necrotic and sloughy tissue diminishing and amount of granulation tissue increasing as the wound moves towards healing. Full wound closure can only be achieved when the wound bed is covered with healthy tissue.
13.1.2 The aim of effective wound management where healing is the end point, is the removal of devitalised tissue from the wound bed whilst protecting and maintaining

moisture balance and encouraging healthy granulation. The presence of devitalised tissue can cause delay to the healing process; it can provide a focus for infection, prolong the inflammatory response, obstruct wound contraction and delay re - epithelialisation.
13.1.3 Necrosis, eschar, and slough are terms used to describe non-viable tissue
13.1.4 During each assessment accurately describe the tissue present in the wound as part of the wound assessment. There may be more than one type of tissue within the wound bed.

13.1.5 The presence of devitalised tissue within the wound can obscure the wound bed thus making accurate assessment of true wound depth or undermining challenging. The true extent of the wound will only be realised once this tissue is removed. Note this may not be the goal of treatment and advise must always be sought from the patient's medical or surgical team before devitalised tissue is removed.
Wound Debridement
Debridement is an accepted principle of good wound care (Wounds UK 2013). It is the active removal of devitalised dead tissue, cell debris or foreign materials from a wound (O'Brien 2002).

13.2.1 Devitalised tissue (slough & necrosis) forms a physical barrier to healing. It does not necessarily indicate presence of infection, but can create an ideal site for bacterial growth. Its presence can prolong the inflammatory phase of healing and prevent progression into the proliferative phase.

13.2.2 Care should be taken when debriding wounds as debridement could reveal underlying structures obscured by necrotic tissue. Debridement should not be performed on ischaemic areas particularly if this is to the lower limbs, necrotic eschar or diabetic ulcers without first seeking advice from either the patient's Medical or Surgical Team or the Vascular Team or Tissue Viability Team.
Methods of debridement

Autolytic – using the body's own enzymes and moisture to rehydrate, soften and liquefy hard eschar and slough. In wound care this is encouraged by the use of modern dressings which promote moist wound healing. (See Trust approved wound care formulary)
13.3.1 For more complex wounds this method of debridement may prove to be too slow and an alternative method should be considered

Mechanical debridement – the removal of loose tissue from the wound with a gauze swab and/or wound irrigation; this is not a recommended method of debridement. Traditionally wet-to-dry dressings were used, but this method can cause severe pain and trauma and should no longer be practiced. Other methods include ultrasonic therapy, pressure irrigation and whirlpool therapy. Evidence to support these methods is limited, and they are not recommended as a first line treatment.

Larval therapy –If urgent and rapid debridement is required, and surgical intervention is not an option, larval therapy can be considered as a viable option. See MSE SOP Safe and effective use of larvae therapy (MSESOP-21012).
Surgical debridement – excision of necrotic tissue to the point of bleeding. Performed in the Operating Theatre setting by members of the Surgical Team.

Sharp debridement:– using scalpel and scissors, as a conservative removal of dead tissue. When managing a wound and it is considered that sharp debridement is required, it is necessary to refer to the patient's doctor, or to the Tissue Viability Team for their advice and wound assessment.
13.3.2 This method of debridement must only be performed by a clinician qualified and competent in sharp debridement.

13.3.3 This method of debridement is contra-indicated except when performed by the patient's doctor, a suitably qualified clinical specialist, or under expert supervision of an appropriately qualified clinician for:
Patients with clotting disorders
Fungating or malignant wounds
Wounds on the face, hands, feet or genitalia
Wounds near the following structures:
Care should be taken when performing sharp debridement on:
13.3.4 Refer to Podiatry or Surgical Teams (Vascular / Orthopaedic) for multidisciplinary assessment of foot wounds.

Debridement and Diabetic Patients Refer patients with diabetes who have foot ulcers and patients with lower limb ischaemia or suspected or diagnosed peripheral vascular disease to the appropriate Specialist Teams (Vascular Team/ Diabetic Foot Clinic / Podiatry). DO NOT undertake any form of debridement until specialist input and advice has been given including a plan of care.
I = Wound Infection / Inflammation
Wound infection is a common complication of wounds. It leads to delays in wound healing and increases the risk of loss of limb and life

13.5.1 The majority of wounds contain micro-organisms (particularly bacteria) and whilst these interact with the wound in different ways, their presence does not generally cause infection or lead to a delay in wound healing. If however the strength and quantity of these micro-organisms start to overwhelm the patient's immune system, a local response (that contained within wound bed margins), or a systemic response (spreading beyond the confines of the wound) will occur. When this happens, the wound is considered to be infected, and as a result of this wound healing becomes stalled, or delayed. This relationship between increasing microbial virulence and host response is described via the infection continuum (See Appendix 5):
13.5.2 The presence of the micro-organisms within the wound causes tissue damage, prolongs the inflammatory phase of wound healing, and can potentially cause systemic illness.

13.5.3 The wound and the wound environment are all factors that can contribute to development of wound infection. The patient's immune response (host resistance) is probably the most important factor and is influenced by a number of local and systemic factors including:
Poorly controlled diabetes
Previous surgery
Radiation therapy or chemotherapy
Conditions associated with hypoxia and/or poor tissue perfusion (e.g. arterial or vascular disease, anaemia, cardiac or respiratory disease)
Immune system disorders
Inappropriate antibiotic prophylaxis (especially in acute wounds)
Poor nutritional status (protein energy malnutrition)
Smoking, alcohol and drug abuse
See Appendix 6 for risk factors for wound infection.

Diagnosis of wound infection should combine clinical judgement and clinical presentation of the wound and the patient.

Regardless of where the patient is being treated ie Ward / out-patient department/ Emergency Department, remove all wound dressings to enable full and thorough wound assessment. Document if this has not taken place with rationale for this.

Patients with diabetic foot ulcers: Send an urgent referral to a Specialist team (Vascular Team / Podiatry / Diabetic foot clinic) in the case of diabetic foot ulcers (signs of infection may be dampened) or if, as stated above, the patient or their wound is deteriorating rapidly.

Biofilm and biofilm management
Have a high suspicion of biofilm involvement where there is delayed healing
Disrupt biofilm by removing it through repeated debridement (type will depend on accurate wound assessment and following discussion with relevant specialist Teams), and maintenance desloughing.
Reduce biofilm formation by use of cleansing with a surfactant and application of an antimicrobial dressing
See wound care formulary for appropriate dressing selection for an infected wound See Appendix 7 for further information on biofilm
Wound swabbing
Indications for swabbing
Screening for MRSA – refer to the Policy for the Prevention and Management of Meticillin Resistant Staphlococcus Aureus (MRSA)
In cases of wounds infected with MRSA refer to the Prevention and Management of Meticillin Resistant Staphlococcus Aureus (MRSA)
Acute wounds with classic signs and symptoms of infection
Chronic wounds with signs of spreading or systemic infection
Infected wounds that have either not responded to antimicrobial intervention, or are deteriorating whilst appropriate antimicrobial therapy has been administered
Where certain microbes in the wound would prevent surgical procedure e.g. prior
to skin grafting

14.1.1 Note: Local wound infection (not spreading beyond the wound margin) is normally diagnosed on clinical criteria and judgement rather than microbial criteria via a wound swab. In this instance routine wound swabbing (or ‘just in case') is not indicated unless there is clear clinical rationale for doing so i.e. MRSA. Swab results should be followed up and actioned accordingly.
Swabbing technique
The Levine technique has been suggested as the most appropriate method for carrying out a wound swab. It should be performed as follows:
Cleanse the wound before taking the swab to remove surface bacteria.
Rotate the swab over 1 cm² area of the wound,
Apply enough pressure to ensure bacteria deep within the wound tissue is obtained.

14.2.1  However it is acknowledge that within the Trust the zig zag technique is the most widely used technique: the swab is rotated across the wound bed without touching the wound edges. See Appendix 8 for practical tips for taking a wound swab.
Appropriate topical antibiotics for wound infection
The aim of treatment is to reduce the microbial load, manage exudate, malodour and pain, and to progress the wound towards healing.
15.1.1 Antibiotics should be prescribed in line with the Trust's antibiotic guidelines

15.1.2 Topical antibiotics are not recommended for routine use in wound management. The risks of toxicity, sensitisation and bacterial resistance far outweigh any potential benefit to the wound. (Flanagan 2000).

Exudate

Exudate mainly consists of water, but also contains electrolytes, nutrients, proteins, inflammatory mediators, protein digesting enzymes (e.g. matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs)), growth factors and waste products, as well as various types of cells (e.g. neutrophils, macrophages and platelets) (Romanelli, Vowden, Weir 2010; Wounds UK 2013).
15.3.1 Exudate is produced during the inflammatory phase of wound healing and plays a vital role in this process. It:
is produced due to the increased permeability of the capillaries
contains proteins, nutrients, growth factors, enzymes which assists healing
bathes wounds with nutrients
cleanses the wound bed
acts as a growth medium for phagocytic cells - white blood cells that engulf and absorb waste materials, bacteria or other foreign bodies.

15.3.2 Acute wound exudate has beneficial properties. Exudate from chronic wounds is not beneficial to wound healing as the composition of it is abnormal. (White and Cutting 2006). It has an altered composition that can interfere with cell proliferation and impedes healing – it:
slows down or even prevents cell proliferation
interferes with growth factor availability
contains elevated levels of inflammatory mediators and activated MMPs8-10.
(M Romanelli, K Vowden, D Weir 2010; Wounds UK 2013).

15.3.3 The amount of exudate produced reduces as wound healing progresses. If a wound is not healing as expected, exudate production may continue and be excessive and prolong the inflammatory process.
See Appendix 9 for types of exudate
Exudate levels

Exudate levels need to be just right and finely balanced. If there is too much exudate or poorly controlled exudate it can pool in the wound bed or damage the surrounding skin and wound edges. Healing may be delayed if there is too little exudate.
15.4.1 Factors leading to alteration in exudate levels:
Stages of wound healing
Systemic factors
Local factors including wound infection
Practical factors including lack of patient concordance to treatment regimes and inappropriate use of dressings
See Appendix  for further list
15.4.2 Examples of wounds with high levels of exudate:
Chronic venous leg ulcers
Burns
Fungating wounds
Inflammatory ulcers such as rheumatoid ulcers of pyoderma gangrenosum
Skin donor sites
Infected diabetic foot ulcers
Impact of excessive exudate production on the patient

The impact of a highly exudating wound can have a negative impact on the patient's quality of life – they by the presence of exudate, and staining to dressings, smell and colour may cause embarrassment and distress and may potentially require frequent dressing change. This may cause further distress and pain for the patient.

15.5.1 An effective wound management plan should aim to contain exudate, maintain patient comfort and dignity, whilst protecting vulnerable structures such as peri- wound skin and the wound bed from trauma, excoriation and / or maceration.
15.5.2 Encourage leg elevation where appropriate to do so, and in line with patient comfort and pain levels.
Advancement of edges

The final stage of wound healing is re-epithelisation which is the active migration of epidermal cells from the wound margins. In normal wound healing granulation tissue form the base of the wound and edges of deeper wounds and /or from islands of epithelial tissue that originates form intact appendages; hair follicles and sweat glands. Concurrent contraction of the wound edges minimises the size and depth of the wound, reducing wound volume and area.

15.6.1 If there is a failure at this stage of the wound healing process, in the first instance review the elements of the T.I.M.E.S framework, to ascertain if there needs to be adjustment to one or more of the elements.
15.6.2 Examining the wound edges can help to identify the wound aetiology
15.6.3 Failure to progress to wound closure may be due to:
Ischaemia
Hypoxia
Infection
Desication
Dressing trauma
Hyperkeratosis
Callus at the wound margin

15.6.4 Inspect the wound margins to ascertain if there is presence of undermining or rolling of the wound edge. Rolled edges can indicate malignancy or an inflammatory cause such as pyoderma gangrenosum.
15.6.5 Accurate wound assessment and obtaining baseline wound measurements enables accurate assessment of the impact of the treatment regime.
15.6.6 Where conservative treatments have failed to achieve complete wound closure, consider the use of advanced therapies:

Topical Negative Therapy – this must only be commenced if deemed appropriate with no contra-indications and following complete and comprehensive wound assessment and with discussion with the patient's Medical / Surgical Team. It must only be commenced and managed by a clinicians deemed to be competent in this therapy.
15.6.7 Consider referral to specialist team (e.g. Vascular or Plastics) if consideration of a procedure such as a skin graft is a potential treatment option for the patient.
15.6.8 Ensure factors that can delay healing are considered and addressed wherever possible.
15.6.9 Consider referral to the Dieticians where healing is delayed or the wound is highly exudating, or if the patient is immunocompromised due to illness or medication.
Surrounding skin

The integrity of fragile skin around a wound can be impaired if conditions in the wound bed are not managed effectively and appropriately; excess exudate can cause maceration and repeated dressing changes due to inappropriate dressing selection can cause skin stripping of the surround skin.
15.7.1 In the presence of wound infection the surrounding skin be appear red, hot to touch, swollen and painful
15.7.2 Failure to assess and manage the surrounding skin, and conditions that can affect it, can affect the wound healing process:

hyperkeratosis – occurs as a result of over-proliferation of keratin-producing cells over the surface of the skin, which results in increased thickening of the epidermis and dermis. The affected area needs to be exfoliated to remove the dead tissue – this can be achieved safely and easily with a monofilament debridement pad or cloth.
dermatitis – this is an itchy epidermal and dermal inflammatory reaction of the skin and the cause needs to be identified to ensure appropriate treatment to resolve the issue.
cellulitis – is an acute, painful infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue and requires immediate intervention with appropriate antibiotic therapy, pain relief and support to the tissues.
oedema – requires elevation and/or support of the tissue to assist in the reduction of the swelling cause by the fluid in the interstitial space.

maceration/excoriation – can occur when the dressing selected is unable to manage volume of exudate being produced and so overflowing onto the surrounding skin. Reassessment of the wound dressing product is required and the skin protected with a barrier product to protect from further injury.
Wound Cleaning

Cleaning the wound and surrounding skin is one of the cornerstones of wound care The aim of wound cleansing is to remove contamination form the wound bed with minimal pain to the patient and minimal trauma to the tissue within the wound.
Cleansing helps to:
Remove loose material,
Remove excess exudate and debris
Remove remnants of older dressing materials
Disrupt biofilm / biofilm reformation
Facilitate accurate wound be assessment wherever possible
(Murphy et 2020)
16.1.1 The wound should be cleansed at each dressing change. See Appendix 11 for practical tips on wound cleansing
16.1.2 Select the appropriate wound cleansing solution and use in line with Manufacturers guidelines.

16.1.3 The wound cleansing solution used depends on the condition and appearance of the wound bed, for example if there is sloughy or necrotic tissue, unhealthy granulation tissue, or if wound infection is either present or suspected.
16.1.4 Select a Trust approved surfactant (see wound care formulary) where there is either:
Wound infection present
High suspicion of wound infection
Excessive sloughy/ necrotic tissue
Unhealthy granulation tissue
16.1.5 For wounds where are there are no clinical signs of wound infection use sterile normal saline to cleanse.

16.1.6 Use of potassium permanganate must be prescribed by the patient's medical or surgical team as the cleansing agent where clinically indicated. (e.g. highly exudating lower leg wound(s). The amount of warm water required to dilute must be according to the manufacturer's guidelines.
16.1.7 Document the cleansing solution used and if there are specific directions for use in the patients wound care plan.
Documentation

All patients who have a wound will have a wound assessment chart commenced on identification of the wound regardless of aetiology. This must be updated at least weekly or on change of wound condition if this happens between planned reviews.

16.2.1 All  patients  who  have  a  wound  must  have  a  completed  and  accurate  wound management care plan in place. This must be updated at least weekly and on change  of  condition.  It  must  clearly  set  out  aims  and  objectives  of  wound management and include wound dressing regime and dressing change frequency and planned review / evaluation dates.
16.2.2 All patients should have documented record of wound progress or deterioration in their clinical record and a documented plan to address wound healing complications
16.2.3 All patients who have, or who require a wound  swab should have this clearly documented in their medical notes and this should be actioned and followed up accordingly

18.7.1 Base dressing change frequency on the following:
The ability of the dressing to successfully control exudate, and the necessity to treat the wound bed.
Dressings should be changed where exudate covers more than 50% of the outer dressing layer.

Granulating and epithelialising wounds will benefit from long periods left undisturbed.

Exudate management
At dressing change examine the exudate on the dressing that is removed. To review, colour, viscosity (thickness), amount and odour
Protect the peri-wound skin by the use of a suitable dressing and skin protector
Once exudate has reached the outer dressing, when staining is present, a dressing should be changed
Select a dressing that is able to manage the amount of exudate present (see wound care formulary)
Dressing change frequency should consider the exudate levels and adjusted accordingly.

Appropriate dressing selection for wound infection
Refer to the Trust wound care formulary for antimicrobial dressings available for use
Always follow Manufacturers guidelines for use
If necessary / required liaise with Tissue Viability for advice and support when selecting an appropriate antimicrobial dressing
When using an antimicrobial dressing remember the following:
Only use an antimicrobial dressing where there is either an increased risk of infection or clinical signs of infection are present.
Do not use routinely for non-infected acute wounds, diabetic foot ulcers or uncomplicated leg ulcers.
Avoid long term use of antimicrobial dressings
Follow the two week challenge:
Discontinue the product if no improvement seen after two weeks & re-evaluate the wound.
If improvement seen within two weeks and the signs of infection have abated stop the antimicrobial dressing and continue with a standard dressing
If improved but clinical signs of infection not fully resolved, continue for a further 2 weeks with regular reviews if clinically justifiable.
Pain
Pain experienced by patient although extremely subjective and variable from patient to patient falls into the following categories:-
a deep dull constant pain
a superficial burning type pain
a neuralgic type pain
an ischaemic type pain
pain resulting from cellulitis

19.1.2 Appropriate action taken to alleviate the pain and effective monitored and reviewed appropriately.

data.text: Appendix 2: Layers and functions of the skin
The skin is the largest organ of the body, comprising 15% of the body's weight & reflects the individual's emotional and physical wellbeing. It consists of three main layers:
The epidermis,
The dermis
The subcutaneous tissue

The epidermis: The outer layer of the skin. It does not have its own blood supply and is provided with nutrients from blood vessels in the dermis. Whilst in general it is extremely thin (<0.5mm) it is thicker on the soles of the feet and the palms of the hands as these need more protection.

The Dermis: The inner layer of the skin lies under the epidermis and is thicker than the epidermis. Its thickness varies across the body ranging from 0.3mm - 3mm. The dermis provides the epidermis with nutrients and oxygen.
The dermis contains:
blood vessels
nerve fibres
sweat glands
hair follicles
sebaceous (oil) glands
Subcutaneous Tissue
Consists of fat and connective tissue
Larger blood vessels and nerves in the skin are present.
Forms a protective layer over the internal organs.
Has an important role in regulating the skin and body's temperature.
The size of this layer varies across the body.
Functions of the skin:

table_items.text: Heat is lost or conserved through the skin via different thermoregulatory systems.
This allows us to experience touch. Extensive networks of nerves run through the dermis allowing individuals to feel pain, itch, heat, cold and pressure.
Waste products are excreted in sweat – this contains water, albumin and urea. Sebum, an oily substance secreted by the sebaceous glands helps to lubricate and protect the skin.

Prevents damage to internal tissues from trauma, ultraviolet (UV) light, temperature, toxins and bacteria. Prevents moisture from escaping (except through sweat). Acts as a physical barrier when intact which prevents pathogens and bacteria penetrating through the skin. Presence of sebum, an antibacterial substance with an acidic pH is produced by the skin.
The production of Vitamin D and melanin (pigment) protects against harmful sun rays

data.text: Appendix 3a: Wound categories
Epithelialising wounds

The  start  of  epithelialisation  is  when  the  wound  is  showing evidence of a pink margin or isolated pink islands on the wound surface. This usually occurs once the granulation tissue is level with the surrounding skin. The cells at the edges of the wound multiply and begin to migrate into the injured area. Uninjured hair follicles also act as islands of epithelialisation. The colour of the tissue is pink to white with a smooth surface appearance.

data.text: Treatment aim is:
to complete the healing process and
prevent damage to new epithelium.

Dressings  should  be  non-adherent  and  maintain  a  low  level  of  moisture  at  body temperature. High levels of moisture kept on epithelial tissue will cause a breakdown of these cells and begin the granulation stage again and could cause over-granulation.
Appropriate dressing selection
Low/Non adherent dressing
Silicone based foam dressing
Hydrocolloid
Vapour permeable films
An appropriate secondary dressing may be required. Selection will depend on factors such as wound site, exudate levels, conformability, patient comfort and pain levels.
Granulating wounds

Granulation is the healing phase of repair. New blood vessels are formed in the form of delicate loops of capillaries which have ‘budded' away from the damaged blood vessels in the wound. These loops grow into, and fill the wound cavity. Fibroblasts migrate into the wound area and synthesise collagen fibres which, in turn, form a network to support

data.text: the new capillary loops.
Appearance
Healthy  granulation  tissue  is  bright  red  in  colour  and  granular  in  appearance.  Dull granulation tissue may indicate local infection.
Granulation tissue is very delicate being easily damaged and made to bleed.
Treatment aim is to
promote granulation by maintaining a moist wound environment whilst removing excess exudate which is considered a harming agent in chronic wounds.
avoid damage to delicate granulating tissue.
Over-granulation

This refers to an abundance of granulation tissue that protrudes from the wound. In many cases the presence of over-granulation is not detrimental to healing and can be left untreated. It can become problematic however, if healing is delayed due to the prevention of re-epithelialisation. Sometimes this tissue increases exudate levels and can cause discomfort in the wound, as well as bleeding easily.
Causes of over-granulation

The causes are not clear but it may be due to a failure in the wound to progress from the proliferative stage of healing. This can be associated with wound inflammation, infection or friction. The presence of over-granulation can sometimes indicate malignancy within the wound.
Tissue Viability Team
Advice should be sought from the Tissue Viability Team if the wound management aims are not achieved within a reasonable time.
Appropriate dressing selection
Dressings should protect the new capillary loops whilst effectively managing exudate.
Foams
Absorbent dressings (e.g. wound pad that will require primary dressing)
Hydrocolloids
Hydrofibre (Aquacel extra, aquacel ribbon)
Antimicrobial (clinical signs of infection present – liaise with the Tissue Viability Team
An appropriate secondary dressing may be required. Selection will depend on factors such as wound site, exudate levels, conformability, patient comfort and pain levels.
Sloughy Wounds

Slough is devitalised tissue. It forms when dead cells and/or bacteria accumulate in the wound exudate. Due to the large numbers of leucocytes slough is yellow or white in colour. It can be dry or wet in nature. The removal of slough can reduce both exudate and odour.

data.text: A yellow fibrous layer can appear in the wound bed that is not slough. This tissue can remain in the wound bed and will not be detrimental  to  wound  healing.   It  is  made  up  of  a  collagen-rich  matrix  secreted  by fibroblasts and it provides the scaffolding for new blood cells and granulation tissue.

Caution should be taken as fascia, tendon or bone can have the appearance of slough to the inexperienced clinician. Unless the causative factor of the dead tissue is identified and removed, necrosis and slough will continue to be present in the wound.
Treatment aim:
to remove the slough, excess exudate and prevent infection.
Tissue Viability Team
Advice should be sought from the Tissue Viability Team if the wound management aims are not achieved within a reasonable time.
Appropriate dressing selection
An appropriate dressing should be able to loosen the slough and maintain the moisture balance at the wound bed.
A dressing that ‘wicks' the exudate away and prevents maceration can be very effective in speeding up healing.
Hydrocolloids
Hydrofibre
Hydrogel sheet
An appropriate secondary dressing may be required. Selection will depend on factors such as wound site, exudate levels, conformability, patient comfort and pain levels.
Necrotic wounds
Necrotic wounds are black, grey or brown in colour and consist of devitalised tissue.
Necrotic  tissue  will  delay  healing  and  can  promote  infection especially if it becomes moist.

data.text: Necrotic tissue lacks leucocytes which are required to deal with dead tissue and bacteria. Unless the causative factor of the dead tissue  is  identified and  removed  where  possible,  necrosis  and slough will continue to be present in the wound.
In most wound situations necrotic tissue needs to be removed as quickly as possible.

Fungating malignant wounds

Fungating  wounds  are  a  devastating  complication  of  cancer which  often  indicate  poor  prognosis.   They  are  caused  by infiltration  of  the  skin  from  a  local  tumour,  haematological malignancy or metastatic spread from a primary tumour. They present  as  either  a  crater-like  ulcer  indicating  a  destructive process, or as raised nodules.

Wound care should focus on symptom control, promoting comfort, preventing damage pain, and/or bleeding and enhancing quality of life. Debridement, if needed should be autolytic, to limit bleeding.
Control bleeding

Skin care- this will help with comfort, a feeling of cleanliness as well as odour control. A barrier film or skin protectant applied around the periwound area can help control skin maceration from moisture. Non-adherent dressings can also protect sensitive skin.

Within the Trust different ways are used to remove dead tissue: Autolytic debridement - the body uses its own enzymes to breakdown the dead tissue. Infection/inflammation – we need to be aware of the signs of wound infection and how to manage this. There may be obvious clinical signs of wound infection; or there may be more subtle signs (see page 20). page 20 sets out the signs of inflammation. Remember: signs of infection can be much less obvious in a patient who has diabetes. Be aware of the differences between the signs and symptoms of inflammation, and those of infection. Both of these states can prevent healing. The types of dressings that may be used are set out in Appendix 3a

Moisture imbalance - too much or too little exudate can disrupt the healing process. In a highly exudating wound, the surrounding skin must be protected as it can become damaged. Barrier products such as cavilon no sting film are available to use on the surrounding skin if assessed as being appropriate. If the exudate is thick, purulent (foul smelling), green, or the exudate level suddenly increases this may indicate wound infection. The types of dressings used depends on if there is wound infection or not and on the level of exudate.

Advancement of wound edges – Usually the epithelial cells cover the wound surface from the wound margins. This stage is unlikely to happen if 1. devitalised tissue is present at the wound margins, 2. if exudate levels are high, 3. if there is wound infection or 4. if there is underlying issues that have not been addressed.

data.text: Appendix 5: Wound Infection Continuum - signs and symptoms

table_items.text: Non proliferating micro-organisms within a wound. Does not damage the host and a host response is not evoked

Do not harm the host or delay healing. This indicates the presence of microbes in a wound, but with no host response. This is a normal state for a healing wound. Treatment: Moist wound healing should be promoted. Antimicrobial dressings are not required.

Wound infection occurs when microbes move deeper into the wound and multiply at a rate that invokes a host response. Local infection is contained in one area, structure or system. In a chronic wound this localised infection often presents with subtle signs (covert) signs which may develop into the classic signs of infection The treatment aim is to reduce the microbial load and promote healing. Antimicrobial dressings may be required.

Multiplying organisms spread from the wound and invade surrounding tissue. A host reaction is triggered. Signs and symptoms of infection extend beyond the wound margins. Deep tissue, muscle, fascia, organs or body cavities may be involved The aim of treatment is to reduce the microbial load, manage exudate, malodour and pain, and to promote healing. A wound swab is required to isolate pathogens and direct treatment plan - topical antimicrobials may be required (see Trust approved wound care formulary for details), and oral antibiotics.

Microbes have now caused a host response. Systemic infection from a wound affects the body as a whole with microorganisms spreading throughout the body via the vascular or lymphatic systems. Systemic inflammatory response, sepsis and organ dysfunction are signs of systemic infection. the patient will be systemically unwell with possible pyrexia, tachycardia etc

data.text: Appendix 7: Biofilms

The role that biofilms play in wound chronicity is not yet fully understood. Chronic wounds are thought to be more susceptible to biofilm formation and it is generally accepted that biofilms are present in 60%–100% of non-healing wounds and their presence somehow delays or prevents wound healing.

Chronic wounds are known to be poly-microbial with most species identified as being and planktonic  in  origin  –  these  are  free  floating  non-attached  single  bacteria.  In  biofilm formation it is thought that planktonic bacteria form colonies and encase themselves in an extracellular polymeric substance that adheres to the wound bed. This process can occur between 2-4 hours. The colonies of biofilms are then able to grow, communicate with each other  using  a  process  known  as  quorum  sensing,  and  protect  themselves  from  the patient's response. In this way they are not removed by the individual's neutrophils and macrophages. A mature biofilm may be present within the wound between 2- 4 days. More simply biofilm can be understood as an aggregate of bacteria tolerant to treatment and the host defence.

Biofilms within a wound do not display the usual signs and symptoms of wound infection, or initiate a host reaction. They cannot be identified through wound swabbing as they are attached to the wound bed. They are difficult to treat as they are able to gain resistance to antimicrobial products and antibiotics.

Identifying the presence of biofilm is often based on the clinician's observations and assessment of the wound bed. In chronic wound Pseudomonas, for example, often forms colonies of biofilms and can be identified by colour and smell.
Identifying biofilm in chronic wounds
Biofilm colonies may not be present across the entirety of the wound bed. The clinician may have a high suspicion of the presence of biofilm on wound assessment due to:

Gelatinous material that is easily removed from the wound surface that reforms quickly
Management of biofilms within the wound bed
The management of biofilms within a chronic wound should be based on disrupting the biofilm cycle. This can be achieved by combining vigorous wound cleaning and on-going wound debridement

Appendix 8: Practical tips for taking a wound swab
Explain to the patient that you are going to take a wound swab and the reason
Cleanse the wound with normal saline to remove excess debris (slough, necrosis, dried exudate)
Wipe away any excess normal saline with sterile gauze
Change your gloves and apply sterile gloves
Use a sterile swab straight from the package if the wound is moist. If the wound is dry, moisten the swab using normal saline (a moist swab provides a more accurate result)
Make sure the swab only comes in contact with the wound surface

Different wound swab techniques can be used. In this Trust the ‘zig zag' technique is used; rotate the swab between your fingers in a zig zag motion across the wound bed. Do not touch the wound edges.
Label the swab correctly with the patient's identification details, date and time of sample, wound site. Make sure it is taken to the laboratory as soon as possible
Swab results should be followed up and actioned accordingly by the patient's medical/surgical team.

Appendix 11: Wound cleansing and practical tips for wound cleansing
Cleansing the wound helps:
Remove dead (devitalised) tissue, and other unwanted products (for example old dressing material). If left in the wound, this could lead to delays in healing.
Remove excess exudate
Sometimes to see the wound bed and edges more clearly
Promote the right environment in the wound to support healing.
Cleansing the skin surrounding the wound (10-20cm from the wound edges) helps:
Remove dead skin scales, and other debris, as well as sweat and sebum. If left untouched the right situation for bacteria and fungi to grow could be created.
Remove excess exudate or dried blood
Practical tips for cleansing the wound and surrounding skin:
Have all the equipment required for dressing change before you start the procedure
Make sure the patient has been given appropriate pain control if they need this before dressing change

Cleanse the skin around the wound, and the skin that has been covered by a dressing or bandages. For example if a patient has wounds on their lower legs that have been dressed with bandages cleanse up to their knee.
Use separate pieces of gauze to cleanse the wound and the surrounding skin. This will help prevent cross contamination.
Cleanse the wound using the gauze and apply gentle pressure but only as long as the patient can tolerate this. Dispose of the gauze in a clinical waste bag.

If a surfactant such as Prontosan or Octenilinin wound irrigation solution is required, soak the gauze in the solution and place on the wound. Leave in place for the amount of time advised by the manufacturer's guide before removing.
Gently dry the wound and surrounding skin.
Remember good care for the surrounding skin – apply a moisturiser (preferably the patient's own) once the surrounding skin has been cleansed and gently dried.
The wound, and surrounding skin, should be cleansed at each dressing change.

Avoid removing the dressing and leaving the wound exposed for a long period of time before redressing it; wound temperature is important and if a wound cools down because it is exposed for a long time it can have a negative effect on the healing process
